image.altText: A woman named Fiona Bain walks along wearing dark sunglasses.

props.synopsis: A coronial inquest into the death of Cleveland Dodd hears a nurse who was on duty the night the teenager self-harmed in his cell in Unit 18 describe the facility as being like a "war zone". WARNING: This story contains the name and image of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: 'The staff were on the front line of a war': Nurse's diary exposes youth justice conditions

image.altText: Neethu sits on a chair with her husband behind her, his hands on her shoulders.

props.synopsis: When Neethu Thomas attended hospital with a small amount of bleeding and cramps in her 38th week of pregnancy, she didn't expect to almost die. Questions are now being asked about her treatment.

title.children: Mother left in coma, uterus removed after traumatic birth at WA maternity hospital

image.altText: Penny Wong sits with her arms crossed in the Senate

props.synopsis: In floating the possibility of Australia recognising a Palestinian state, Penny Wong said the quiet thing out loud and in doing so tore open one of the most sensitive decades-old debates.

title.children: Wong planned to say the quiet thing out loud. Her critics were quick to pounce

image.altText: A woman holding photos of her three children.

props.synopsis: In Japan, thousands of children are cut off from their mum or dad every year as victims of a system that incentivises parental child abduction. The country will soon introduce laws that will enforce joint custody, but it's only caused more division.

title.children: 'Love you no matter what': Izumi's kids were photographed calling for her death, but she won't stop fighting for them

image.altText: CCTV of a man in a red hat about to punch another man.

props.synopsis: Detectives from the Gang Crime Squad are investigating a March 31 assault in Bunbury that left an 18-year-old man in hospital with a broken jaw a week before another man was randomly attacked.

title.children: Spate of violence in WA's biggest regional city has detectives probing 'unprovoked' assaults

image.altText: Rubbish strewn around natural bushland, sofa pieces, furniture, clothing

props.synopsis: Mattresses, tyres and household waste dumped in 'pristine' bushland are an increasingly common sight, with many blaming tipping costs and a reduction in verge collections for the behaviour.

title.children: Illegal dumping in Kalamunda's pristine bushland 'sad and disrespectful'

image.altText: A number of adults in protective headgear, surround a boy in a padded room preparing to grab him. All faces are blurred.

props.synopsis: A damning review finds the NDIS Quality and Safeguards Commission failed to close a controversial program that put children with disabilities at risk of death despite reports from officials and families that it was using prohibited restraints.

title.children: Former judge criticises NDIS commission's response to controversial autism program

image.altText: A large outside view of a compound

props.synopsis: Refugee advocates are concerned the men are being denied access to human rights websites, have been stripped of the ability to use messaging apps to contact loved ones, and are experiencing high levels of distress and anxiety.

title.children: First details emerge of rapidly filling Nauru detention centre following four boat arrivals in six months

image.altText: Three people walking a dog through a car park at Trigg Beach.

props.synopsis: Police have shot dead a dog at a popular Perth beach after the animal became aggressive towards officers and attacked a number of other dogs.

title.children: Police forced to kill dog that attacked officer, two dachshunds at popular beach

image.altText: Mackenzie holding a netball with a serious look on her face.

props.synopsis: Mackenzie was knocked unconscious during a netball game and suffered a concussion that she says still affects her today. New research could help identify which children will have long-term symptoms so early intervention can take place.

title.children: Melbourne researchers make breakthough in children's concussion with blood protein discovery

image.altText: A few old brick buildings stand next to the ocean.

props.synopsis: Traditional owners overseeing the revival of Cossack in Western Australia's north-west say it could become a "ghost town" again, accusing the state government of losing interest in the project.

title.children: Popular heritage town home to prestigious art award  'closed' amid dispute with state government

image.altText: SA Police officers outside a bus with luggage arriving in Alice Springs.

props.synopsis: The first rotation of South Australian police officers arrives in Alice Springs as the youth curfew continues in the outback town.

title.children: As the Alice Springs youth curfew continues, extra police arrive from SA

image.altText: A black and white photo of planes flying over jungle.

props.synopsis: Almost eight decades after their aircraft crashed in waters south of Papua New Guinea, Australian crew members have been identified, as Twiggy Forrest searches for his late wartime relative.

title.children: Bone fragments in PNG underwater wreck identified as Australian WWII crew

image.altText: Jim Chalmers at a press conference with his mouth closed.

props.synopsis: Australia may be a competitive nation on the sporting field, but our corporate giants have a habit of taking out smaller rivals before they can challenge their supremacy. New laws are aiming to make that a little bit harder to do.

title.children: The Chalmers offensive: Why corporate marriage proposals are under fire

image.altText: A male lion lying on grass.

props.synopsis: Animals acted in bizarre ways during the recent solar eclipse seen across North America. Here's why that happens.

title.children: How do animals react to a solar eclipse?

image.altText: A man kisses the Israeli flag as protesters wave the Palestinian flag

props.synopsis: Penny Wong's decision to weigh into the fraught diplomatic argument over a two-state solution has prompted furious debate.

title.children: What does the government mean when it says it supports a two-state solution?

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie carrying an umbrella surrounded by journalists

props.synopsis: Former Seven Network producer Taylor Auerbach's lawyer has made further submissions to the court in Bruce Lehrmann's defamation trial.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's 'silence was deafening' in response to new evidence, Taylor Auerbach's lawyer says

image.altText: A group of Australian and New Zealand netballers contest the ball during an international match.

props.synopsis: Netball becomes the latest sport to restrict transgender participation in elite women's competition with a new policy that only transgender players who have "not experienced the biological effects of testosterone" can play at international level.

title.children: World Netball bans transgender players from international competition

image.altText: A screenshot of someone being prompted to use the Palestinian flag emoji when they type the word Jerusalem into their iPhone.

props.synopsis: When iPhone users who have downloaded the latest software update type in the word "Jerusalem", they will see a prompt for the Palestinian flag emoji. Here's why that may have happened.

title.children: Why are some iPhone users seeing a Palestinian flag emoji when they type 'Jerusalem'?

image.altText: Phil Beresford

props.synopsis: The fire tore through Macco Feeds in Williams, consuming 400 bales of hay and damaging equipment including a front-end loader.

title.children: Hay fire causes major damage at WA mill as farmers struggle with feed shortage

image.altText: An open cut mine under a cloudy sky

props.synopsis: Papua New Guinea's government approves a joint military and police operation to crack down on illegal mining and remove "squatters" at Porgera gold mine, just months after the site's grand reopening.

title.children: PNG's mega Porgera gold mine just reopened — so why is the government sending in police and military forces?

image.altText: Annie Louey wears a brown suit and white shirt with brown buttons, she's smiling and standing in front of a pink wall

props.synopsis: It's Pay Day! Comedian Annie Louey explains how she spends 0 per cent of her income on rent or a mortgage, and why — despite growing up in a frugal home — she is in the habit of paying the bill instead of splitting it when she eats out.

title.children: Comedian Annie Louey makes more money now than when she was working nine to five — but it took a minute to get there

image.altText: Newcastle MP tim crakanthorp standing in NSW Parliament. He is giving a speech to the House.

props.synopsis: The state's corruption watchdog has terminated its investigation into former Labor frontbencher Tim Crakanthorp, finding there are no prospects of finding corrupt conduct in relation to landholdings linked to his wife's family.

title.children: ICAC terminates investigation into former Labor minister Tim Crakanthorp

image.altText: A Port Adelaide AFL player is hugged by a teammate (wearing #4) after kicking a goal.

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide forward Jeremy Finlayson has been found guilty of breaching the AFL's code of conduct and suspended for three matches for using a homophobic slur toward an Essendon player at Adelaide Oval on Friday night.

title.children: Power forward Finlayson banned for three games for 'very hurtful' homophobic slur

image.altText: They stand in the bush toasting with champagne

props.synopsis: A community group is celebrating after the state government refused to let an exploration company clear habitat vital to the endangered Carnaby's black cockatoo. But the company has vowed to appeal.

title.children: 'Staggered, delighted': Conservationists pop champagne after win for critical bird habitat at proposed mine site

image.altText: An Aboriginal woman reads Where's Spot with an Aboriginal woman in a blue shirt.

props.synopsis: The Australian not-for-profit has bested authors, illustrators and organisations including Neil Gaiman and Quentin Blake to win a global award, in honour of the creator of Pippi Longstocking.

title.children: Australian charity beats Quentin Blake and Neil Gaiman to win $725,000 international literary award

image.altText: Roman Abramovich holds the Club World Cup trophy in one hand

props.synopsis: A complex web of money, Russian politics and English football is unravelling in the United Kingdom.

title.children: How an English football club got caught up in the aftermath of Russia's invasion of Ukraine

image.altText: A man surrounded by cameras.

props.synopsis: Laws which passed the ACT Legislative Assembly today mean jurors who do their own research will face criminal penalties of up to two years in jail.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann mistrial leads to new jury laws in ACT

image.altText: Karoline Dawe and Kylie Ward wearing nice evening dresses outside a gala event.

props.synopsis: The boss of a peak national nursing body is one of three executives who have been stood down pending an independent investigation into "potential financial irregularities" within the organisation.

title.children: Nursing executives stood down pending investigation of 'potential financial irregularities'

image.altText: A large silver truck drives off into a pink sunset.

props.synopsis: Transport bodies say heavy freight traffic on the highway caused by the Trans-Australian rail line's closure after flooding in Western Australia has put truck drivers at greater risk. It comes after three men died in a truck crash on the road last week.

title.children: Reports of inexperienced truckies, unsafe driving on Eyre Highway amid extra freight traffic caused by rail closure

image.altText: A crowd holding their phones in the air with the phone torches illuminated.

props.synopsis: Community leader Sissy Austin, who publicly shared her own experience of violence in bushland near Ballarat last year, has organised a rally against men's violence for Friday evening.

title.children: Hundreds expected to pay tribute to allegedly murdered women at Ballarat rally against men's violence

image.altText: A three-panel split image showing a smiling young blonde woman, harsh bushland, and a smiling middle-aged blonde woman.

props.synopsis: About 16 per cent of all women allegedly killed by men in Australia this year have died in the Ballarat region. It may sound like an absurd figure, but data shows the rate of family violence in the Victorian town is higher than state and national averages.

title.children: What the hell is going on in Ballarat? With three women dead in two tragic months, it's a question worth asking

image.altText: Image shows congestion and traffic delays. You can see cars, grey road on a gloomy day.

props.synopsis: Mayors in Sydney's inner west tell an inquiry their early warnings of Rozelle Interchange traffic chaos were ignored and the problems are now likely to remain for years.

title.children: Rozelle Interchange warnings ignored and traffic chaos to last years, inquiry told

image.altText: A jail booking photo of Ethan Crumbley beside his mother Jennifer Crumbley and dad James Crumbley.

props.synopsis: In 2021,15-year-old Ethan Crumbley entered a Michigan school with a gun and started shooting. Now, his parents are going to jail for his actions. Here's how the events unfolded.

title.children: The parents of a school shooter have been jailed. Here's how it unfolded

image.altText: British reality TV star Louise Thompson lying in a hospital bed with a hospital gown on

props.synopsis: Thompson, who has previously posted about having ulcerative colitis, says the stoma bag "represents life" and she does not want to hide it.

title.children: British reality TV star Louise Thompson praised for normalising stoma bags with 'brave' Instagram video
